DOC.SECOND: US Troops Think They Almost Got Noriega First Day
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch from Panama by Steven Komarow of The Associated Press and Robert Kearns of Reuters.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops think they almost got Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on the first day of the intervention when they broke into a fortified house, finding signs of panicky flight and, by one account, ``vats of blood'' and animal entrails. The abandoned office and house, on the seacoast near here and close to several U.S. military bases, was stormed by U.S. soldiers on Tuesday, about six hours after the U.S. invasion began. ``The cigarettes were still smoking in the ashtray and the women left their purses, which no woman would ever usually do,'' a soldier familiar with the house said Thursday. But Noriega was not to be found in the retreat that had been specially built for him, and soldiers continued scouring the countryside Friday for the deposed leader wanted in the United States on drug charges. The American soldier, who would not give his name, said troops who saw the house spread the word that one room was apparently devoted to the occult, with blood and entrails. Military officials could not immediately confirm the soldier's account. Saying the house might have been booby-trapped, officers would not allow reporters and photographers inside, Gen. John Huston said. Another soldier, Sgt. 1st Class Joseph Torregrossa, said there were bizarre trappings in another of Noriega's quarters, his private office in Panama's military barracks at Fort Amadar. ``When we went inside, there were all of these expensive prints, but he also had a portrait of Adolf Hitler and a lot of expensive weapons, mostly automatic,'' Torregrossa said. ``He had German Lugers, Israeli Uzis, all sorts of real sophisticated stuff.'' Travel restrictions, including a nighttime curfew, were still in effect Friday, and new fighting was reported with men loyal to Noriega attacking the headquarters of the U.S. Southern Command. A two-hour tour through a bombed-out shopping district that once was a Noriega stronghold showed scenes of near chaos as thousands of looters seized refrigerators, microwaves, automobile tires, gasoline and other goods. They cheerfully stopped, however, to shout ``Viva Bush, Viva Bush'' or ``Bush, Bush, Bush'' as they waved to soldiers and journalists. One held up a knife sharpener and joked, ``It's a present from Bush.'' Noriega's nine-building headquarters was a smouldering hulk, its windows blown out by tank and artillery fire. It was closely guarded by dozens of U.S. troops. Less than a mile away, the body of a man, face down and shirtless, lay trapped in the crushed wreckage of a sedan. A U.S. infantry sergeant said an armored personnel carrier rolled over the car after the driver was seen passing out AK-47 rifles. An old section of the city around Noriega headquarters contained many of Panama City's poor and homeless, but they had largely abandoned it, taking refuge in quarters provided by U.S. military at the American-owned Balboa High School in the suburbs, U.S. officials said.
